New Records: Luka Modric became the oldest goalscorer in Euros history at the age of 38 years and 289 days.
Mattia Zaccagni scored the second-latest goal scored in a game at the Euros (excl. extra time) behind Hungary’s Kevin Csoboth against Scotland (99:33).
Key Match Events: Luka Modric scored a goal just 33 seconds after his penalty miss.
Mattia Zaccagni scored the winning goal for Italy in the 98th minute.
Alessandro Bastoni gave Dominik Livakovic his first real test in the 27th minute with a powerful header.
Davide Frattesi’s handball in the box led to a penalty for Croatia in the second half.
Pre-Game Insights: Italy had a tricky test in Group B with Spain and Croatia alongside them.
Croatia needed to win this match to make it through to the knockout stages.
Post-Match Reflections: Luka Modric’s goal looked like it had given him an opportunity to extend that national team record further this summer, but Zaccagni’s goal might have spelled the end of the legendary midfielder’s international career.
Italy will face Switzerland in Berlin on 29 June after qualifying for the last 16.
Miscellaneous Highlights: This is just the second time Croatia have failed to win any of their group games at an edition of the UEFA European Championship finals (D2 L1).
Each of the last four meetings between Croatia and Italy in all competitions have been drawn.
Croatia have now failed to score each of their last three penalties taken in major competitions.
